Beers that are red in color tend to be some of the most attractive and appealing beers out there. Yet, no one seems to agree on what exactly a red ale is; though most seem to be either an amber ale or an IPA that happens to red instead of golden, copper or orange. Cigar City Tocobaga Red Ale seems to be a little of both as it has the malty sweetness of an amber, but the strong hop profile of an IPA. Consider it a red IPA I suppose.

I poured a 12oz can into a red wine glass. It was canned on 10/1/15 and cost $2.49 ($0.21 per ounce). Thanks to Mike for this can!

Appearance: Magenta/maroon hue; very dark though plenty of murky sediment bits can be seen floating around. Pours to a thumb-width, tan, foamy head which laces and retains well.

Smell: Citrusy and floral hops for sure. Clean, bright, classic. Theres definite malt sweetness in the nose as well.

Taste: Theres a lot going on in this beer, and yet its also a bit simplistic. For a hop-forward brew its quite malty (I swear that sentence makes sense). Citrusy bitterness and flavor right away; especially that of ruby red grapefruit. But theres also a lovely sweetness thats difficult to ignore. Definitely the flavors commonly found in amber ale  caramel or toffee or treacle  though not cloyingly sweet. The bitterness is quite strong, which isnt surprising considering the 75 IBUs. Its also intensely dry and seems to absorb all the moisture out of the mouth after each swig. Alcohol is prominent as well and creates for a slight medicinal character; thankfully, its not all that annoying or distracting. Overall, the taste here is pretty nice.

Drinkability: At 7.2% ABV, Cigar City Tocobaga Red Ale is a pretty strong brew by most measurements. This creates for a bold palette, though the actual delivery is no burden whatsoever. Mouthfeel is thick with a slight sticky sensation to the texture. The alcohol imparts warmth and the hops do linger to dry out the tongue. Probably a good beer to stand up to savory food.

RATING: 7/10

Une bouteille de 12 oz qui dévoile une robe ambrée et passablement embrouillée.  Le col mousseux construit lors du versement saccroche et laisse quelques traces sur la paroi du verre.  Le premier nez est fait de fruits sucrés et dagrumes.  Le second et les suivants confirment dautres choses houblonnées comme de la résine, des herbes fraîches et des notes dépinette.  Jai limpression que la levure en est une anglaise.  Je me trompe?  Cest fort possible.  Au goût, mes papilles captent de bonnes saveurs de tangerine, de fleurs, de fruits rouges et de notes de pin qui sétendent sur une base maltée caramélisé de moyenne envergure.  Sur le palais, le liquide est de moyenne densité.  Sa texture mapparaît crémeuse et son pétillement est plus que modéré.  La finale se fait sur des notes amères modérément intenses : jai des saveurs dherbes et dagrumes et de résine qui restent collées dans le fond de ma gorge.

12 oz bottle gifted by Kan. Thanks! 74th Cigar City Rating. Pours a rich toasty amber copper hue. A good hazy quality, with some glowing sunset edges. A frothy thicker offwhite head sits atop, stays as a decent layer and laces ok overall. Aromas are toasty and toffee, biscuits and sweetness mix with dry floral and earthy hops. Gentle wisps of citrus mix into the fold. Biscuits, bread, and toast. Simple Red with a decent hopping on the nose. Initial is medium bodied with a pretty potent hop front. Dry florals and grass, a good dose of dry grapefruit, gentle pine hit the palate up front. Middle stays dry and earthy, biscuits and touches of toast mix into the fold, a thorough dose of crystal malts. Not as sweet as anticipated, offering a healthy dryness, hopping, and toast. Finish is earthy, some nuttiness, floral and grassy hops, gentle resinous pine. Simple, dry overall. Ok.

Pours a clear and copper beer with an offwhite head. The aroma is malt, caramel and hops with citrus. The flavor follows the nose. The palate is sweetness with some bitterness. Overall a good beer with a good balance.

On tap at brewery.  This was delicious.  Pours nice reddish brown with huge nose of tropical fruit.  Tastes all hopped up and great.  Tons of grapefruit and melon.  Some piney bitterness and light maple syrup.  Loved it
Bottle.  Bomber.  Pours cloudy red with a white head.  Aroma of grapefruit, pine, caramel.  Nice red ale.

Pours light amber with a thin tan head. Aroma is hoppy, malty with some earthy notes. Flavor is citrus, hops, earthy and caramel. Has a nice dry finish.  Light bodied with moderate carbonation. Still cant believe this was 7.4%.

12oz bottle, gifted from Kan! Thanks. Pours a dark dense red with an off white head. Aroma has lots of tropical fruit with a sharp sweet cotton candy and toffee malt character, some piney and grapefruit hop notes in the background. Flavors are a bit astringent in their bitterness and use of crystal malts, big pine, citrus, and melon hop notes that move towards an earthy quality as they attempt to dry out the finish.
Long bitterness throughout, and a healthy malt sweetness. Body is syrupy at times. Its not a bad beer as the hopping is nicely excessive but the use o crystal is just not my thing. This really reminds me of a smaller Bigfoot.
pours a nice brown color is a slight bit of amber. really hoppy and not too malty. rough mouth-feel  with a strong bite at the end. creamy color head . lots of emphasis on the hop front.

750 ml bottle from tricyclist- thanks again, Matthew! Pours a semi-cloudy amber color with a small off-white head. Aroma of amber malts, earthy hops, toasted sugar, and some leafy, earthy notes. Sweetens as it warms. The flavor isnt as sweet, with some subtle earthy bitterness- amber malts, earthy hops, dry grains, leaves, and caramel. Light-bodied, with a dry, malty mouthfeel and moderate carbonation. We couldnt believe this was 7.2% ABV. Not bad.
750 ml. Bottle pour.  Dark color with red hues.  Nice white head.   Hoppy grapefruit on the nose.  Hoppy with nice smooth bitterness.  Nice red.

UPDATED: NOV 21, 2011 22oz. Bottle (at 7.2%ABV per the Bottle):  Got in trade from biggsbowler; THANKS Randall!  Aroma of malt, light hops, light caramel, and a hint of Earth.  Poured deep amber/orange in color with a large, creamy, dense, tan head that greatly diminished but lasted throughout.  Hazy.  Sparkling.  Flavor is light to medium bitter and lightly sweet.  Tastes of malt, leaves, hops, Earth, slight tea, and citrus.  Medium body.  Average texture.  Average carbonation.  Malt, hop, citrus finish.  7.2% is completely hidden throughout.
Solid hopped up red ale. rich, robust, and tasty. This is what a big, bold red ale should be. A little thick, and over hopped for the true style, but this is an Arrogant Bastard slayer.

4 oz sampler / pour at Cigar City tasting room....did two of these....the initial taste grabbed me despite all of the other wonderful CC beers I sampled....great hop forward initial taste along with a smoothing taste I cant describe...this is one FINE beer

The hazy reddish orange brew sits nicely in my Cigar City snifter with a nice sized white head on top.  It slowly disappears into the liquid and leaves a slight bit of lacing around the glass.

The nose bursts with citrus like hops.  A lot of grapefruit and orange in there.  Quite a moderate amount of malts in the nose as well.

Not much different in the taste.  The hops come at you first.  They are slightly earthy along with the citrus notes.  Id say there is even some tropical fruit tastes in there as well.  This has become common in their hoppy beers.  A caramel malt backing is present and gives some balance to things.  But the hops are first and foremost.
Bottle @ Early Winter Tasting,  Odense, 2011. Pours ruby copper with a creamy head and lacings. Peach and grapefruit. Sweet caramel. Sticky. Really dry and hoppy end.
Hazy red amber with a small off-white head. Sweet caramel and juicy citrus hop aroma. Sweetish caramel and biscuit flavour with citrus hops and a good bitterness

nice amber pour. great frothy head on this beauty of a beer! malt aroma  with some hops thrown in. creamy when it hits your tongue. sweet malt up front with some hop bitterness on the finish. I see what the fuss is about!

This one was probably a bit past its prime.  The hops were very muted but still retained some fruity spicyness.  The overall beer seemed a bit more malt aggressive then I had anticipated.  Not bad though.

Draught @ the brewery. Pours a hazy light brown with a small off-white head. Aromas of citrus and pine. The hops really come out in this one with a really nice roasty malt backbone; perfect balance. I wish I could get this in Illinois!!!
pours amber color with thin white head. nice hop/malt up front with a lingering floral taste very nice red thanks -juiceisloose-
750 ml pours a brown/amber color with a medium white head.  Aroma of sweet roasted malt with light floral hop.  Evenly balanced beer, a real good amber.

Pint at the CCB tasting room.  Unfiltered orange-brown.  Steady beige head.  Big seawater, fresh west coast hoppy aroma.  A well done Amber for sure.  Soapy, piny, resiny.  Medium to full bodied, with some nice balance.  Nails the style, this is a really solid offering.

From tap at Three Penny Taproom. Pours hazy deep amber with a small, creamy and white head. Aroma is fruity, pine hoppy. Light toasted malty. Bitter, fruity, crisp hoppy and pine. Citrusy to grapefruity flavoured. Light toasted malty. Bitter and dry finish.
Malty aromas are dominant, hops are complement to the Malts in the flavor. About even balance with malt tasting of strong amber.

GABF 2011.  Clear rusty amber caramel with a rocky light beige head. Amazing aroma of juicy tropical fruit--mango, apricot, light pineapple, grapefruit, with some sweet caramel backbone. Lovely hop aroma. Unfortunately taste was not as good. Got some bitter grapefruit, a little pine, some herbalness, with a malt profile that didnt balance enough. Not overtly bitter, just not complex or nuanced. Just another overhopped beer.

Pour from a bottle. Murky amber red color with an off white head. Aromas were of sweet malt. Medium and nice mouthfeel. Mild bitter hop presence along with the crystal malt sugar. Not a whole lot else going on. Pleasant beer but would not search it out.

bottle thanks to kiefdog.  poured amber with a white head.  aroma was floral, caramel, and some slight pine.  flavor had a big malt backbone, citrus, and pine.  body was medium with low-medium carbonation.  I wish that I would have drank this fresh.

The aroma is strong with citrus and pine hops as well as caramel malt and a bit of candy sweetness. The appearance is deep amber with a medium head. The taste is like the aroma. The palate is smooth. Overall a really good amber.
UPDATED: OCT 23, 2011 Hazy brown color, beige head.  Aroma of plain caramel.  Taste of bitter pine.  Interesting.

(750ml bottle courtesy of Markwise!).  Pours a clear amber color with an off-white head.  Arom has lots of citrusy hops, sweet malts and hard candy.  Taste follows suit with the maltiness and some hoppy bitterness.  Medium bodied with a sticky texture.  Bitter finish.  Not bad, but not my cup of tea.
Nice red color. You can snell the hops. Very smooth. There is a subtle caramel flavor and a sweet finish.

Bottle shared at CPK, London, thanks to Paul. Pours rich ruby with a foamy, off-white head. Toasty malt aroma with plenty of hops. Fully sweet flavor in this guy, heavy malts, bread, some toast. Yeah, just big toast and sugar. Full bodied with average carbonation. Mild warming finish with very good balance. Plenty sweet, some pine and grapefruit. Very solid.

Pours red with white head.  Smells of floral hops.  Taste is strong grassy hops with a solid malt backbone.  Alcohol is apparent in this one, but not overwhelming.  A little sweetness is detected but a nice bitterness is left by the aggressive hopping of this one.  Delicious.

UPDATED: SEP 29, 2011 Bottle.  Deep amber color with a thick off-white head.  The aroma is nice; shows a caramel and pine needle dominant scent but with also some grapefruit and a touch of toffee.  I must say, this is probably better than I thought it would be.  Nice and clean, not one of these over the top Imperial Red/Strong Ales with one too many ingredients.  Theres definitely some caramelized sweetness but not overdone, along with pine hops, a little citrus, and a toasty component.  A little bit of the 7.4% shows in the finish as this warms up a bit but not much of it.  Ill be the first to admit the strong(er) Red is not really my thing but this was quite solid.

Bottle shared with Scott and Jay thanks to Pineypower. Poured a solid looking red/amber with an average sized thick beige foamy head, very thick syrupy body. Aroma of caramel, grains, pineapple and toffee. Full chewy body with stronger carbonation and an average to lingering duration on the finish. Flavor of bread, toffe, caramel, citrus rind and hint of pineapple. Really good stuff. Im not from Florida but CCB rocks.
Bottles ! ... pours reddish with off white fluffy head... hops, berries, flowers notes aroma.... the flavor is sweet, hoppy, berries, flowers.... nice full mouthfeel .......hoppy bitter finish...

Bottle. Kudos to Hopscotch for bringing this to me! Its a beauty. Pours hazy amber with a creamy long lasting off white head. The aroma is berries, flowers, herbs, citrus and loads of caramel. Lovely citric hoppy flavour with notes of berries, peach, passion fruit and sweet caramel. I just love the double amber ales!
Botella. Cloudy orange. Small off.-white head. Fruity wheat yeasty fresh pleasant aroma. Good filling mouthfeel. Fruity yeasty wheat like flowey sweet mild well lasting good lasting bitterness,

UPDATED: SEP 14, 2011 Bottle from Paul Unwin. Pours reddish/orange/brown. nose is red berries, with raspberry dominating but cranberry in there too. Also a bit sea salty. Taste is sour a bitter with just a hint of caramel malt.

Bottle - 750mL crowned. Ruby-amber with a tall, dense, foamy beige head. Aroma is fruity (mainly citrus but also tropical fruit notes), floral hops, soft spicy hops and sweet malt. Taste is spicy hops, big citrus, tropical fruit notes, light caramel, and sweet malt. Floral hops throughout as well. Body is medium with a strong, bubbly carbonation. Finishes with big hop notes (mostly spicy hops and citrus based), big tropical fruit notes, sweet malt, light caramel, and floral notes.
Another good beer from Cigar. Nice caramel notes, spice, vanilla....with notes of orange, pineapple....good mouthfeel.

Appearance: browns of the forest and the colors of long fallen leaves. Off-white head leaves lace around a thin film.

Nose: green hops  pine trees and pine needs with the essence of forest. Crunchy underneath  crisp twigs and pine cones. Nondescript spices, thin apple crisps, and the musk of older forgotten times. Fir and pine meets sweet crunchies.

Palate: clean. Crunchy caramelized sweetness underneath while atop twigs, pine needles, fir trees, fall leaves mingle together. Apple skins in the back with more twigs and whole cinnamon sticks. Whole hop cones  sticky and parching. More hop cones and pine in the breath. Nicely attenuated.

Final Thoughts: I drank a lot of this beer when it was on draft at Hurricanes. A lot. So much so I forgot about these tasting notes and so here we are, months later, and it remembers as good as it tasted.
Bottle split with Pat and Vin. Pours a deep, hazy red body with nice lacing. Aroma is fresh pine and floral hop. Mouthfeel is medium and well carbonated with nice notes of floral hop.

750ml.  pours a deep red with a 2 finger off white creamy head - settles down to a thin lacing.  big citrus hop nose with a great caramel malt balance with a bit of spice and vanilla... almost perfect nose - so well balanced.  medium body - very smooth and creamy throughout with notes of pineapple, orange, light cranberry, raisin, caramel and red grapes.  dry and bitter finish with lingering sweet malts and dark fruits.  excellent amber / red ale!

Bottle thanks to Mike. Pours out an attractive moderate amber color with a small white head. Aroma is of some light caramel, some citrus hops, sweet pineapple and some light biscuit. Taste is complex with a lot going on, notes of resiny tropical fruit hops, some citrus, caramel, light bread, pineapple and a touch of alcohol on the slightly dry finish. Crazy complexity with a perfect blend of flavors. This one was a standout.

Picked this bottle up at Connecticut Ave in DC. So happy that this is finally out in bottles, as Ive been looking for it ever since it was first released. Served in a Mikasa tulip.

Pours a dark blood-amber color with a two-finger off-white head and quite a bit of sticky lacing on the way down. Thin cap throughout. The nose carries a really nice burst of fresh citrus and pine with slight tropical notes. Underneath that is a bit of caramelized sugar and bready sweetness. Really quite nice and nails the description for a hoppy amber.

The flavor falls back a bit from there, as the hop flavor isnt as prevalent as the nose would lead you to believe. However, there are certainly still plenty of hops. Nice brown sugar and caramel sweetness plus backing malt. Medium body that is fairly chewy and has a bitter finish that is slightly dry. Good carbonation. Really, really solid effort all around. Well worth the wait.

Serving type: bottle

Bottle; Pour is murky golden amber with a frothy, fine bubbled off white head that does retain well in this glass. Light, spotty lacing in this glass. The nose is caramel, pine, and cream from the head. The flavor profile is sweet, creamy, and bitter. Caramel, Pine, grapefruit, toast; This is a great red, and another good brew from CC

Big Bottle from Secret Santa. Pours clear dark copper color with khaki head. Big piney aroma with some caramel. Moderately sweet caramel flavor with lots of pine. Medium body with average carbonation. The finish was pretty dry.

Another winner from CCB, i really enjoyed this .. . Pours out a deep ruby sunset, great foam .. . sweet maple, caramel and citrus - wonderfully balanced and abv well masked.. . does anyone know how to take penalties .. . This was a good beer and dangerously drinkable .. . Save me, Jeebus!

Pours a beautiful clear amber red with a white head. Nose is pungent citrusy floral hops with sweet malts backing it up. Flavor is very hop forward with nice amounts of caramel malts taking on in the finish.

UPDATED: JUN 10, 2013 Poured from a 750ml bottle into a New Belgium globe.

Appearance: Pours a deep red-amber color with ruby highlights and a 2-3 finger frothy pale tan head. Excellent head retention and lacing.

Smell: Pineapple, coconut and pine with a touch of sweet malt. Smells a lot like their White Oak Aged Jai Alai.

Taste: Pine and bitter citrus up front followed by a hint of toasted malt in the middle before ending with another round of bitter hops at the finish. There are undertones of sweet citrus and coconut throughout. Aftertaste is bitter with just a light amount of sweetness that really balances it out. The aftertaste really lingers.

Mouthfeel: Medium-to-full-bodied with a high amount of carbonation. The hop oils are very sticky and really coat the palate.

Drinkability: Very high drinkability. I wish they offered this in 4 or 6 packs.

Overall: Excellent beer overall. Not your typical American Amber/Red Ale since it is so hoppy, but the category isnt too precisely defined in the first place. I would rank this among the best Cigar City beers that Ive had. Highly recommended.
Bottle pours a hazy amber with an off white head. Scent of hops and bread. Taste is sweet malt then bready with a dry hoppy finish.

Best red ale Ive had to date. Nice hoppy, pine and citrus aroma with succulent notes of caramel and sweet malts. Poured a dark orange/brown color with a nice off white head and sloppy lacing. Tasted like an IPA with a touch more malt. Very hop heavy but with caramel and sweet malts poking through. Grapefruit, orange, and yes, jalapeño in the taste. Not the heat, but the floral qualities. Not bitter at all. Very well balanced and drinkable to no end. Great stuff.

Aroma: pine sap and floral hops, lots of toasty and caramel malts, some sweetness.  Pours a hazy red, off-white head with average retention.  Flavor: quite malty with lots of citrus and piney hops to balance.  Caramel malts, somewhat bready and toasty, fairly bitter but well balanced.  Medium-full body with medium carbonation, smooth and velvety on the palate.  Solid amber ale, really enjoyed this one.

750ml bottle.

Pours a dark hazy amber with a big creamy beige head that recedes pretty quickly to a thin collar and leaves really nice lacing.

Aroma is hoppy with some pine resin and lots of caramel malts and a bit of toasted bread.  There is a little bit of wood character as well, interesting nose for an amber.

Taste has a little more citrus than the nose, with some oranges and white grapefruit up front giving way to the caramel malts, bread and hints of sweet fruit.  Lightly bitter finish, roasty.

Mouthfeel is medium to full bodied for an amber and really creamy with strong carbonation.

This is an excellent amber, one of the better ones Ive had lately with a nice balance of sweetness and hops with that distinctive CCB woody character.  Good stuff.

Pours a dark hazy amber color with a moderate sized light tan head that leaves some lacing. Aromas of caramel and citrus. Flavors of caramel and malt upfront with a sweet and slightly bitter citrus finish. Medium bodied. Overall a very nice Amber probably the best Ive had.

Sample at the tap room. This brew pours a hazy reddish color with a medium thin light beige head that recedes steadily. Rings of lacing on the glass. Aroma of hops and caramel malt. Medium body with flavors of grassy hops, toasted malt, caramel and citrus. The finish is hoppy with a fruity aftertaste. Above average overall.
Dark amber color with a hop and caramel aroma.  Hop bitterness dominates the flavor with caramel undertones.  Nice beer.

Lansdale Beer Fest 2011.  The third beer tried.  Dark amber pour, lots of citrusy aromas.  Flavor was crisp and hoppy with still the caramel sweetness present in an amber.  Good hoppyness and bitterness.  Very much enjoyed.

750ml bottle courtesy of smith4498. thanks, jason! pours a hazy, reddish-orange with a thick, creamy, off-white head leaving tight rings of lace. aroma is very nice with fresh, citrusy hops, red berry pulp and seeds, pine esters, and light toffee with a touch of dry grass graham cracker. flavor is great, classic red ale, with sweet toffee malts, bitter pine esters, and light notes of strawberry and red grape with hints of tangerine, orange peel, and subtle vanilla. palate is on the richer side of medium bodied with light carbonation and a bittersweet, citrusy finish. overall, a damn nice red ale.
Draft at Cigar City tasting room.  I really enjoyed this one.  Nice flavor and aroma.  Goes down quite easy with a well-hidden 7.4%.
Pours hazy amber with white head.  Aroma is caramel, citrus and piney.  Taste was grapefruit and sweet caramel. Very smooth and the alcohol is well hidden.  Very enjoyable.

UPDATED: JUL 24, 2012 Had this on tap at Proof the other night.  I dont have a formal rating, just a vibe:  toasty with floral grapefruit hops.  creamy good palate.  apricot and orange in the aroma.  Good - would like to try again.  7-24-2012: bottle from six pack.  Cool to see this in sixer form now.  Brown pour with solid light tan head.  Aroma is big resiny citrus - apricot and grapefruit.  Tastes are juicy tropical fruit, caramel malt, grain, floral.  Medium creamy palate.  I stick to my previous score - think this is a little underrated.

Hoppy red, the caramel malt is very much in the secondary. Light red colour, very lacey, with minimum head. Big hops, some carmael. 
On tap at the brewery. Meets the style, popular locally, fresh. Hoppy aroma, good drinkabilty, average mouthfeel.

Tallahassee, Fl - Proof - on tap served in a snifter. Dark orange pour, off-white head, nice sticky lacing sticking to the edge of the glass. Sweet fruity aroma, with some juicy fruit gum accents, a hint of spruce. Flavor has some sugar cereal sweetness, grapefruity citrus and a hint of cherry juice. Mouthfeel is thick and has just the right amount of spritziness. Overall, very decent.
On tap at CCB on 4/28/11. Clear amber pour with a medium beige head. Aroma of grassy hops and a bit of malt. Hoppy flavor with a bit of tropical fruit and a lasting bitter finish.
Pours hazy red with a nice note of citrus in the nose.  Citrus turns into a nice deep feel of malt that drives a smooth finish.
Big red citrus ale with lots of piney hops trying to dominate the fruitiness. Pretty smooth on the palate but overall it still is flavorful and enjoyable.

On tap at the brewery: Pours a transparent bright copper amber with a stringy-lacing white head.  Has a big, fresh grapefruity hoppy nose and lightly sweet toasted caramel malt.  Starts with good fullness and light toasted malty sweetness with lots of fresh resiny hop flavor and citrusy bitter balance before a drier bittersweet finish.  An enjoyable and drinkable imperial red ale.

A reddish amber ale wit ahtin off white head. In aroma, sweet butterscotch with light raisinous notes, light hopping. In mouth, a lightly hopped beer, with light watery malts, interesting herbal peppery notes, ok beer. On tap at brewery, Jan 5 2011.

Had this on tap at the house of 1000 beer in new ken, nice place. Im not sure if this is the right spot for this beer. Even tho it had the same name there was no red in the beer nor was it mentioned in the name at the house. It was just plain pale yeller. Big grapefruit aroma. Nice alabaster head. Seems to be more of a IPA than an amber. Fruity background. Very little CO2. IPA -ish finish. Yea, I bet there are more than a few cigar city tocobagas out there.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: I saw that this beer has gotten really good scores, but it didnt agree with me.  Most of what I got out of this beer was alcohol.  The Tocobaga pours a dark red color with a reddish hue.  There wasnt much of a head or lacing with this beer.  The nose and flavors were mostly bland, with only alcohol, lights hops and a very mild tone of malts were noticed.  I was really disappointed in this beer.

Fruity hoppy nose - grapefruit and floral notes, some tropical. Lots of caramel malt, some residual sugars stick around to add sweetness. Pours darker amber than most. Nice lasting creamy head and lace. The flavor is sweet and malty up front - caramel, toast followed by IPA level hoppiness in the form of grapefruit and floral notes and afformentioned tropical fruit. Creamy body with residual sweetness and lingering resins. Stronger than most ambers. Rather unique for the style. Nice.
tap at blind tiger - hoppy rye and dry, spice and hoppy. pine, citrus and mint. tropical notes, nice and malty.
UPDATED: MAY 22, 2012 Beautiful hoopy red ale.  The nose is citrus, pine.  The flavor is all olf the above, plus caramel.  The finish is piney hops.  Medium in body.  Excellent.

Tap at BT.  Pours a deep dark amber with a thin lasting sticky head.  Aroma is fresh citrusy and tropical hops, medium caramel sweetness, toffee, pine and mint. Flavor is caramel malt, burnt toffee, honey, light molasses, good clean malt, and hops, light grass, big citrusy hops, grapefruit then big tropical mango and passionfruit hops- amarillo seems big here.  Very nice double red!

About as good as it gets for this style. A very nice mellow aroma of fruits and malts from a slightly reddish pour with a small off white head. The flavor is IPA like with a bunch of sweet fruit up front and a ton of citrus and pine hops in the back end. A wonderful after taste that lingered for my walk from Hawthornes to Nodding Head.

UPDATED: DEC 6, 2010 Draft. Pours a clear copper red color with a slight tan head. Hoppy citric aroma on the nose along with sweet malt and some woodiness. Nice lace left on the glass as it settles. Medium mouthfeel with good carb. The flavor starts off with some sweetness followed by flavors of citrus hops and the earthy/woody notes in the nose. For a red ale this is nicely balanced without being too maltyl. Very easy drinking as well. Ends with a lingering bitterness from the hops.

Mini growler thanks to Ibrew2or3. Pours a dark red/brown color with a large white head. The aroma is rich fruity hops and caramel. A distinct amber ale flavor with a large pine and fruity hop bite, loads of caramel, juicy, resins, light bitterness. Close to a IPA for sure. Imperial Amber? Yep. I guess this is really a American Strong Ale, its smooth though, a nice toasted malt and caramel flavor throughout. Very good.
Reddish brown in the glass with a beige head. Bright citrus hoppy nose. Nice combination of hops and malty caramel sweetness on the palate. Excellent amber ale.

Draft at CC. Poured a clear dark copper color with an average fizzy off-white head that was mostly lasting and had good lacing. Good earthy & leather hop & toasted malt aroma. Medium body with smooth texture and soft carbonation. Medium to heavy bitter flavor with a medium bitter finish of moderate duration. Good brew.

Mini-growler from Redlight.  Hazy brown with lacy froth.  Nose is spicy orange and dried apricot with a breath of pine.  Medium body, oily, sticky, with a soft soothing buzz.  Taste is honey, juniper, clove and rye.  Excellent; ups the ante on Irish Ales.

Tap at Blind Tiger. Pours a slightly hazy amber with medium white head. Lots of hops (maybe cascade and simcoe) in the nose but little else. Flavor has notes of grapefruit and hops. Nice rush of hops at the end with some juiciness. Solid IPA finish.
on tap-pours a n offwhite head with amber color.  Aroma is citrus/herbal, some light malt.  Taste is ctrus hop bite, some light malt.

On tap at Blind Tiger with Joey Redner.  Pours a deep amber red with a white foam head.  Has an aroma of roast, caramel, citrus, and some pine.  Has a sweet toasty taste with a nice breadiness and a nice hop hit.  A big malty hoppy brew.  Some nice velvety caramel notes on the finish.  A creamy mouthfeel.

mini growler via trade with smith4498 - Pours a clear mahogany color with a 3/4 finger thick light tan head.  Faint tiny spotted lacing.  Aroma is floral hops and lightly toasted malt.  Flavor is more balance.  Again, floral hops and toasted malt.  Medium body.  Not your typical Irish ale, but very tasty none the less.  Thanks Jason.

On tap at the Blind Tiger during their Cigar City event.  Pours a clear ruby orange with a thin to medium sized white head.  Spicy toast, nutty malt, and a good helping of hops on the nose.  Flavors follow the nose with a lot of spiciness, more toast and thick malt.  Nice hop presence throughout and big chewy earthy malt on the back end.

Growler thanks to Smith4498. Pours a clean coppery orange with one finger of sandstone head. Nose is strong in the hop department, spicy with rich citrus and bready undertones and a hint of peanut shell. Flavor is similar, peanut hull is more upfront, as is the spicy/hoppy character. Palate becomes increasingly sharp.

Growler shared by emacgee.   Pours a hazy orange-tinted red with a thin sudsy white head.  Nose is plentiful grassy hops, some sweet cotton candy, but really pretty one-dimensional and slightly watery.  Flavor is quite bitter like i just ate some crushed Dramamine.  Needs some malt balance.  Bad.
On tap at BX.  Dark reddish/brown in color.  Piney, earthy, spicy notes with a somewhat bitter start.  Good stuff...
The best red ale Ive ever had.  Generously hopped, but still bursting with red ale tones of darker fruits and hints of malty goodness.

Golden amber in color with a long lasting foamy white head.  Floral and cirtrus  hops aromas with a hint of herb and caramel.  Creamy mouthfeel gives me mostly earthy hops with not much malt to speak of.  A plesant beer overall that drinks lighter than 7%.

Growler poured a hazy amber with a small lingering amber head. Aromas of tangerine, pink grapefruit, tropical fruit, light pine, light earthiness and light biscuit. Palate was light to medium bodied and crisp. Flavors of biscuit, tangerine, tropical fruit, pink grapefruit and a hint of pine with a crisp lingering moderatly bitter fruity finish.

Growler from the brewery. Pours clear dark copper color with khaki head. Big piney aroma with some caramel. Moderately sweet caramel flavor with lots of pine. Medium body with average carbonation. The finish was pretty dry. With the amount of sweetness I was expecting it to be more sticky. A decent red ale with a big dose of hops.

Very hoppy and a bit boozy for any kind of amber or red and certainly an irish ale.  Piny hops dominate and the palate is slick and smooth.  Lots of caramalt.  An ok offering, not their best and certainly not their worst.

Draft at Redlight Redlight.  Pours a sticky amber color.  Hops in the aroma with some light caramel.  Flavor is more hops and caramel with a nice balance.  The finish is the key, with the resiny hops lingering for some time.  Great fresh hop flavor without being too sweet.   Great brew.

Growler sample courtesy of HOPSHUNTER. Pours opaque copper  brown with light tan head. The aroma is earthy, dark roasted malts, spicy hops and a touch of chocolate and burnt malts. The taste starts a bit bright with spicy hops, some grapefruit and then a wedge of hoppy earthiness. Toward midway it picks up a pleasing malt roastiness, a touch of burnt malts and chocolate. Nice hoppy roasty brew.
Growler thanks to Drowland. Pours clear reddish brown with tan head. Nose of citrus, malts and hops. Taste of pine, hops and malts with dry finish.

32oz growler. Thanks to Jason for the trade... Pours a dark amber caramel toffee brown with a thin light beige head... Aroma of citrusy hops and an equally balancing toffee and caramel malt. Semi-sweet overall with a fair bit of bittering... Flavors are a continuation of the same with a balancing act of citrus piney hops and sweeter caramel malt. Finishes on quit a bit of a bittering note. A little extreme in the finish but Nottingham too bad overall.

A: The pour is a really nice bright ruby color with a thin layer of off-white head.

S: Plenty of hops on the nose. Theyre primarily of the oily pine variety, which is always welcomed. Theres some toffee and bread, along with a bit of citrus.

T: The hops are again the dominant characteristic. Quite bitter, which is always nice, with some earth, pine, and citrus notes. The caramel, toffee, and bread are still there as well. Theres also a hint of roast at times.

M: The body is medium as is the carbonation.

D: I really had no idea what this beer was until I came on here to review it (though I sort of figured it was some sort of red ale). Pretty nice, actually.

Growler. This one pours a very cloudy, dark reddish amber color and topped by a thick, pillowy head of beige colored foam that shows good retention. Small thin spots of lacing scatter on the glass. The aroma is really hop forward showing tons of bitter grapefruit and orange along with some sticky pine. Caramel and big, bready malts comprise the base. The flavor follows and is hoppy up front with the bitter grapefruit and orange peel to go with the sweet caramel and bready malts. Full bodied and slightly sticky with moderate carbonation to go with a slightly dry and bitter finish. If you tone the abv down a bit you would have a real winner. Still a really nice red ale.

Growler.  The pour yields a cloudy, swirly, dark reddish-orange body with a thin, whirling, beige tinted film at the head.  Tiny spots of lacing dot the glass.  The nose is very hoppy, loaded with grapefruit rind and fragrant orange blossoms, along with a touch of pine.  Underlying malts are big and bready, showing heaps of caramel and a bit of pils malt.  Theres a distinct booziness that kind of puts a damper on what is otherwise a very nice aroma.  Flavors are again very sharp and hoppy up front, giving oily grapefruit and orange peel amidst ample caramel and bread malts.  Big bodied and slightly syrupy, the palate sports moderate to slightly less than moderate carbonation and a semi-dry, somewhat sticky finish.  Reminds me alot of Oskar Blues Gordon.

Tap @ CCB.  Hazy amber pour with a medium egg shell head.  Citric nose with a good amount of caramel and pine.  Medium body with a good amount of carbonation, slightly sticky.  Flavor is fairly balanced but still hop forward, big notes of orange, pine, caramel, grass, and toffee.  Very easy to drink.

32oz growler from brewpub. aroma is hard crunching caramel and boat load of pinecones riding shotgun.  appearance is slightly murky amber/red with filmy head and drippy lacing all around.  flavor is resinated blood oranges, lightly caramelized over an open flame.  deep caramel is present but crushed by onslaught of hops whos bitterness hangs out for eternity.  intense brew!

On draft at CCB. I have had this beer a few times, and I am really growing to like it more and more. Pours a hazy light amber to copper color with off-white one finger head. Aroma is sweet and malty with notes of caramel, citrus, grapefruit, pine, light spice. Flavor is sweet and malty with notes of citrus, caramel, grapefruit, floral esters. Medium body with a floral hop finish. Another great offering from CCB.
Growler shared by duffmansw .Pours reddish brown color with tan head. Aroma is fresh pears and hops. Taste is very malty with a nice hop bitterness. Good carbonation. Great irish brew.
Growler sent by Hopscotch....Pours red orange with a thin ring head. Aroma is sweet and malty... Crisp hoopy bite with a malty finish.. Good stuff, would drink on the regular.

Tims Creation and it is a good one.

A: Pours a nice amber hue with a solid off white head. Good retention and some nice chunky lace.

S: Wonderful sweet yet hoppy. Lots of caramel and toffee. Bold citrus hops with lots of earthy goodness.

T: The sweet candy malts are there up front. The back end is all about the hops though. Very aggressive without being over done. Bold citrus with strong grassy notes.

M: Medium in body, smooth, a bit dry in the finish.

D: Good Really like this one. Look forward to its cousin...the lager version.

Growler thanks to Blazer06.  Pours a slightly hazy reddish-amber color with a spotty off-white head and great lacing.  The aroma is really great - hoppy and citrusy with tropical fruit notes.  Lots of pineapple.  Some sweet caramel malt too.  Caramel malt base on the flavor with a strong and interesting hop profile.  Herbal qualities, pineapple, mango, and grapefruit.  Somewhat palate-wrecking with a nice fairly light body.  Great mouthfeel, very dry.  Awesome red ale overall.  Sort of west coast style.  Impressive.

Thick lacing was left behind from the off-white head, topping a burnt sienna body.  The nose reminded me of the classic Central Florida breakfast of sweetened pink grapefruit with a pint of hoppy beer. Sweet and bitter palate, floral and grapefruit, very light astringency with heaping awesomeness
On draught at tasting room poured copper with a nice head smelled of plums hops and possibly mangoes tasted hoppy and grassy with nice hop and grassy aftertase

9/6/10.  Growler from the brewery.  Cloudy red pour with a bright cream head that lasts and lasts.  The aroma is awesome hops with pine, a hint of pee, some pot, and more.  Awesome.  The flavor is also delish.  Lots of fresh hops again, much the same profile but with a dash more tropical sense, all with a hint of chocolate backing.  Very nice!

Tap @ Cigar City...  Poured a hazy amber with an off-white head. Floral, piney hops on this one with some sweet malts, and a mild yeasty fruitiness.  Dry and crisp with a hoppy finish.  Very much like a Northwest hop profile.
Pours a murky golden. Aroma is hoppy grapefruit. Sweet citrus, excellent earthy profile. Palate is good, medium mouthfeel. Overall a really good beer
